tit.e: Sekimon Shingaku (popularized blend of Buddhist, Shinto and Confucian ethical teachings)
tit.cmt: ・用語集の用語検索によると、初出のときには（）内の説明が必要とのことです。
tit.e: Sekimon Shingaku (popularized blend of Buddhist, Shinto and Confucian ethical teachings)

sen.j: 石門心学（せきもんしんがく）は、日本の江戸時代中期の思想家・石田梅岩（1685年 - 1744年）を開祖とする倫理学の一派のことである。
sen.e: Sekimon Shingaku is a school of ethics the originator of which is Baigan ISHIDA (1685 - 1744), a Japanese thinker in the middle of the Edo period
Sekimon Shingaku is a school of ethics established by Baigan ISHIDA (1685-1744), a Japanese thinker in the middle of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: ・「開祖とする」の部分をestablished byで表して、全体を短縮しました。
sen.e: Sekimon Shingaku is a school of ethics established by Baigan ISHIDA (1685-1744), a Japanese thinker in the middle of the Edo period.

sen.j: 単に、心学ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called Shingaku (Mind school) for short.
It is also called Shingaku (Mind school) for short.
It is also called Shingaku (Mind school) for short.

sen.j: 当初は都市部を中心に広まり、次第に農村部や武士まで普及するようになった。
sen.e: In the beginning it was spread mainly in urban areas, and gradually became popular in agricultural community areas and among samurais.
In the beginning, it was spread mainly in urban areas, and gradually became popular in agricultural communities and among samurais.
sen.cmt: ・beginningの後にカンマが必要なので追加しました。・農村部はagricultural communitiesとしました。
sen.e: In the beginning, it was spread mainly in urban areas, and gradually became popular in agricultural communities and among samurais.

sen.j: 江戸時代後期に大流行し、全国的に広まった。
sen.e: In the late Edo period, it was all the fashion, and its popularity spread nationwide.
In the late Edo period, it was all the fashion and spread nationwide.
sen.cmt: ・its popularityはなくても問題ないので削除しました。
sen.e: In the late Edo period, it was all the fashion and spread nationwide.

sen.j: しかし、明治期に衰退した。
sen.e: However, it fell into decline in the Meiji period.
However, it fell into a decline in the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: ・「衰退する」はfall into a declineです。
sen.e: However, it fell into a decline in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 概要
その思想は、神道・儒教・仏教の三教合一説を基盤としている。
sen.e: Its ideology is based on the theory for unification of the three religions of Shinto, Confucianism and Buddhism.
Its philosophy is based on the theory for unification of the three religions of Shinto, Confucianism and Buddhism.
sen.cmt: ・石門心学は学問なので「思想」はphilosophyとしました。
sen.e: Its philosophy is based on the theory for unification of the three religions of Shinto, Confucianism and Buddhism.

sen.j: その実践道徳の根本は、天地の心に帰することによって、その心を獲得し、私心をなくして無心となり、仁義を行うというものである。
sen.e: The basis of its practical morality is to get the intention of the Tenchi (the world) entrusting oneself to it, to be selfless and be in mu-shin (a state of mind free from delusion) and to do humanity and justice.

The basis of its practical morality is to get the intention of the Tenchi (the world) entrusting oneself to it, to be selfless and be in a state of mind free from delusion, and to do humanity and justice.
sen.cmt: ・mu-shin は表記されていても英文の読者にはあまり意味がないと思われるため削除し、その後の（）内の内容をいかしました。・天地の心、無心、仁義など日本人でも定義の難しい言葉が出ているので、それを英訳して読み手に通じているか定かではありません。
sen.e: The basis of its philosophy of practical morality is to bring your heart into oneness with the spirit of the universe, to be selfless, to achieve a state of mind that is free from delusion, and to observe a code of humanity and justice.

sen.j: その最も尊重するところは、正直の徳であるとされる。
sen.e: What it respects most is the virtue of honesty.
What it respects most is the virtue of honesty.
What it respects most is the virtue of honesty.

sen.j: 一般民衆への道話（どうわ）の講釈と心学者たちの修業（会輔）の場となったのが、心学講舎と呼ばれる施設である。
sen.e: The places where lectures on Shingaku teachings were given to the common people and Shingaku scholars were trained were the facilities which were called Shingaku kosha (Shingaku Schools).

The places where lectures on Shingaku teachings were given to the common people and Shingaku scholars continued their training (Kaiho or support meeting) were the facilities which were called Shingaku kosha (Shingaku Schools).
sen.cmt: ・「修行の場」の部分を「修行を続ける所」と解釈しました。・「会輔」にあたる部分がなかったので補足しました。
sen.e: The places where lectures on Shingaku teachings were given to the common people and Shingaku scholars continued their training (Kaiho or support meeting) were the facilities which were called Shingaku kosha (Shingaku Schools).

sen.j: 明和2年（1765年）に手島堵庵が五楽舎を開いたのが最初である。
sen.e: The first one was Gorakusha that was founded by Toan TEJIMA in 1765.
The first one was Gorakusha that was founded by Toan TEJIMA in 1765.
The first one was Gorakusha that was founded by Toan TEJIMA in 1765.

sen.j: 最盛期には全国に180カ所以上の心学講舎があった。
sen.e: At its peak, there were more than 180 Shingaku koshas around the country.
At its peak, there were more than 180 Shingaku koshas around the country.
At its peak, there were more than 180 Shingaku koshas around the country.
